https://prez.dev/description.@value: A categorization of disciplines or topics that the broad field of Earth science can be subdivided into, i.e. a listing of the Fields of Research, or subjects, to which a geoscience dataset, publication, observation/activity, or entity pertains. The vocabulary also contains relevant disciplines that intersect with the various Earth science fields, such as biological sciences and built environment and design, as well as entries related to collection and heritage management. Notations included are those from the 2020 ANZSRC listing (see History Note) or in common use in the geoscience community.
The study of human cultures through the recovery and analysis of their material relics.

The identification of global, national, state-wide, or local features of geology (such as igneous, metamorphic, sedimentary, stratigraphic, structural, geochemical, mineralogical, paleontological, geomorphical, pedological, and hydrological attributes) that are: (a) intrinsically important or culturally important sites; (b) offer information or insights into the formation or evolution of the Earth, or into the history of science, or (c) that can be used for research, teaching, or reference. Geoheritage is inextricably linked to geoconservation, for the preservation of these sites for posterity.

Studies related to the identification, collection, curation, conservation, interpretation, use and management of cultural and natural heritage, by examining the variety of locations through which this happens such as objects and collections, museums, heritage places, intangible cultural heritage, and international heritage practice.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Collectively, the study of practices, items and places designated as significant, including the investigation and interpretation of past human events (history), the identification, conservation and presentation of significant places, processes and items (heritage), and the study of human cultures through recovered artefacts or relics (archeology). Although history and archeology imply the interpretation of human culture, heritage and museum studies can be applied to concepts of both natural (abiotic or biotic) or cultural significance.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia.
